G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may modify a judgment regarding custody “if the Court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.”

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Plaintiff seeks modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and applicable Massachusetts case law on the basis of a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the welfare and best interests of the minor child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 6 & 39.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction under G.L. c. 208, § 28 (for divorce and custody modifications) and G.L. c. 215, §§ 6 & 39 to modify prior judgments concerning custody and visitation when it is shown that a material change in circumstances has occurred since the entry of the earlier judgment.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts law requires that custody and parenting time orders remain flexible to protect the child’s welfare when circumstances materially change.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for initial custody determinations and for removal of children from the Commonwealth, focusing on the ‘best interests’/‘real advantage’ test and case‑by‑case analysis. It does not address modification of existing custody or parenting-time orders upon a material change in circumstances, nor does it speak to any requirement that such orders remain flexible over time. The cited case therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modification based on materially changed circumstances.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Massachusetts law requires that custody and parenting time orders remain flexible to protect the child’s welfare when circumstances materially change.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The case directly concerns modification of an existing custody/visitation-related order (removal restrictions) and emphasizes that decisions must turn on the child’s best interests, including the evolving circumstances of the custodial parent and available visitation alternatives. The court reverses and remands for further proceedings because the judge failed to consider all relevant factors and notes that more than a year has passed and circumstances may have changed, implicitly recognizing that custody/parenting-time related orders must be revisited as conditions change. While it does not use the word “flexible,” its reasoning supports the notion that such orders must be adaptable to protect the child’s welfare when circumstances materially change.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Because sensitive and significant child-parent relationships are affected by decisions concerning removal, we think that there is here also the need for comprehensive findings and that the interests of the child may be best served by an accommodation ‘which intrudes least on the [liberties] of either parent and is yet compatible with the health of the child.’ … As more than a year has elapsed since the original hearing and circumstances may have changed in the meantime, such proceedings shall include the hearing of additional evidence if either party or the judge so elects….”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: A material change is demonstrated when the circumstances underlying the prior judgment have significantly altered.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies the statutory requirement that a custody modification be based on a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances,’ but it does not define that standard as ‘circumstances underlying the prior judgment have significantly altered.’ Instead, the court holds that relocation alone and a temporary, court-imposed shift in custody do not amount to such a material change, and finds no post-divorce events ‘of sufficient magnitude’ to justify altering custody. The case thus illustrates what does *not* qualify as a material change rather than positively articulating the claimed proposition.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). … There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements….”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: A material change is demonstrated when the circumstances underlying the prior judgment have significantly altered.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/best-interests decision and does not analyze what constitutes a “material change” or “substantial change in circumstances” for purposes of modifying a prior judgment. The only mention of “substantial change in circumstances” appears in a quoted section of the ALI Principles, not as a holding of the court and not in the generalized terms stated in the proposition. Thus, Mason v. Coleman does not itself establish that a material change is shown when circumstances underlying the prior judgment have significantly altered.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]....”

[This is ALI commentary quoted by the court, not the court’s own rule on ‘material change.’]

Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449 (1991).proposition: Relocation that substantially affects the child’s schooling, rest, or development constitutes a sufficient material change.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with the standard for permitting out‑of‑state removal (the “real advantage”/best interests test under G.L. c. 208, § 30) in the face of a surviving separation agreement. It does not frame or analyze relocation in terms of a “material change” standard, nor does it hold that relocation substantially affecting schooling, rest, or development is itself a sufficient material change. The case is about which standard applies (statutory ‘real advantage’ vs. ‘countervailing equities’), not about defining what constitutes a material change in circumstances.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “We must decide what standard the judge should apply to determine whether to grant a request for the removal of children from the Commonwealth: the c. 208, § 30, ‘real advantage’ standard, the ‘countervailing equities’ standard, or some other standard. The statute is controlling over the provision contracted by the parties. Therefore, the statutory standard is to be used, even in this case, where the parties have contracted for consent of the other before removal… The standard to be used… is that set forth by the Legislature in G. L. c. 208, § 30, and interpreted by this court in Yannas.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody determinations.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes the "best interests of the child" as the governing standard for custody determinations and applies it to decide the custody dispute. The court traces the historical roots of the standard, reaffirms that it is the touchstone for custody matters, and interprets the relevant statute as directing the judge’s discretion within that best-interests framework rather than replacing it. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that the best-interests standard governs custody determinations, at least in Massachusetts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children “to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.” ... In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is “best for the child” is firmly rooted in American history... It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) (best interests standard “has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation”).

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody determinations.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody determinations and emphasizes that domestic violence and its effects on the child must be explicitly considered as part of the analysis, but the provided excerpt does not state or reiterate the general rule that all custody determinations are governed by the ‘best interests of the child’ standard. The court applies that framework implicitly and cites related statutes, yet it does not clearly articulate a broad, categorical statement covering all custody determinations. Thus it is weak authority for that specific, general proposition, even though consistent with it.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. ... The Appeals Court’s remand order is designed to do just that. We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260.relevant_excerpt: At school, Michel demonstrated sleepiness, poor eye contact and little interaction with his peers. He vomited frequently, talked to himself in different voices, was preoccupied with violence, and scored 64 on an I.Q. test. When asked about his father, Michel lay on the floor mute and attempted communication in sign language. Neither mother nor father cooperated with recommended psychotherapy for Michel. A treatment team concluded that his psychological distress was a result of physical, emotional, and interpersonal deprivation in his biological home.
